content:
In case you're talking about Global Search, see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/global-search

It is more likely the index needs updating, because your messages somehow got lost.

If those messages are important to you, you probably did create a backup and can restore them from that.
creator: christ1

content:
Thanks Christ1.

Yes, I'm talking about Global Search I think. I've read that page earlier, and it does what it says it does, but when I get the list of results up, I can't open the emails individually.

I have an old profile from 2019 that seems to have a file called global-something-sqlite but I can't get it to open so I can read its contents.

I really don't want to rebuild the global whatever it's called as I think that will delete the emails that are still there. So I'm wondering whether to download an sqlite reader and see if that will show the content.

I'm not very techy so would be glad of any thoughts/instructions for how to restore.
creator: FlightReturn

content:
I've read that page earlier, and it does what it says it does, but when I get the list of results up, I can't open the emails individually.

That tells us the index isn't up to date anymore, hence you need to rebuild the global database as described in the support article. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/rebuilding-global-database

I have an old profile from 2019 that seems to have a file called global-something-sqlite but I can't get it to open so I can read its contents.

I'd expect your problem is with a current profile you're actually using, not with an old one from four years ago. The global-messages-db.sqlite file is just the search index. It does not contain the actual messages. You can open it with a sqlite reader application, but I think you'd just be wasting your time.

I really don't want to rebuild the global whatever it's called as I think that will delete the emails that are still there.

No, it won't delete any messages, because it just rebuilds the search index. If you messages still exist they will be found by rebuilding the index. If they are gone, they will also be removed from the search index.

So I'm wondering whether to download an sqlite reader and see if that will show the content.

I'm not holding you off. But don't be disappointed if it doesn't produce the expected result. Good luck.
creator: christ1

content:
Many thanks for explaining that. I won't bother with the sqlite reader then.

The chap in the page I linked to had the same problem, or what sounded like the same problem, and when he rebuilt it the messages went completely. This is what I'm afraid of: I can currently see the first few lines of them, which is way better than nothing (this is to do with a fairly serious matter, so I need as much as I can get) so I'm afraid if they no longer exist I won't even have the email titles and start of the text.

Hope that makes sense. It's a bit of a risk. I know I wouldn't have deleted them but I did replace my computer at some point so they may have been got rid of during the transfer process. So I don't know if they still exist or not.

Thanks again for your help. I might take the risk or not, gotta think it over.
creator: FlightReturn

content: My suggestion is to join the Beta initiative at https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/102.0/beta-appeal/ I share your concern and have found that, by having the beta alongside the release level, I can see for myself which addons have been updated prior to public release. This also provides you the opportunity to follow up with developers on their plans. Developers are more likely to maintain their addons when they have following of people who use it. I say this because the Thunderbird team isn't responsible for addons, as they are volunteer initiatives. Thanks for posting.
creator: davidsk

content:
da voi chi? Giusto per chiarire, questo è solo un forum di utenti. E nessuno qui vede le tue impostazioni.

Se il problema riguarda una singola mail, è difficile darti delle risposte. Potresti averla cancellata per errore (hai controllato nel cestino?) o potrebbe esserci stato un problema alla chiusura di Thunderbird.

Se invece parliamo di molti messaggi, forse devi fare un po' di manutenzione al database: 1) Fai un backup del profilo -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo 2) Compatta le cartelle -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/compattazione-cartelle 3) Ricostruisci l'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale
creator: @next

content: Why would you want to create a new key every time the old one expires? Unless the old key has been compromised, there is no need to create a new one. You can simply change the expiration date of the existing key via the OpenPGP Key Manager.
creator: christ1

content:
Other than not wanting to have to keep a load of old keys hanging around, it is also a case of future security. The DES, BassOmatic and TEA symmetric ciphers were considered safe once but have since been broken. RSA key sizes have grown over the years as well in step with NIST etc recommendations.

Same goes for MD5 and SHA1 for cryptographic signatures.

Not to mention that keeping the private key hanging around also makes for a great way to fake old signatures should the keys be stolen or otherwise compromised.

So it would be handy to be able to "upgrade" old messages and reduce attack surface by deleting old expired keys. Granted, changing the signature of received messages is out of the question, but at least ensuring the underlying encryption is kept sound is important.

Heck, being able to encrypt the whole inbox regardless of whether the sender used your public key would be nice. But that is outside of the frame for this question.
creator: kjell-reg

content: Click tools, then Addressbook Highlight the desired addressbook Notice the three dots to the right of name. That is a drop-down menu with Export option and that creates a csv file.

content: Well, it's late Saturday night and my brain is a bit fuzzy, but I admit, I've never heard of Braxmail and would be surprised to discover that it is a Thunderbird product. But I've been wrong before. :) From what little I know, Braxmail is an email provider, possibly recommending Thunderbird? Also, to my knowledge there is no Thunderbird Apple Mail equivalent; instead, Thunderbird supports Apple mail. Setup info for that is at https://discussions.apple.com/thread/252865542 If Braxmail users use Thunderbird, then it seems there is no transfer of account needed? Maybe a little more info will clear this up. Let us know. Thank you.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, David. I got interested in the BraX2 phone, as it was developed by Rob Braxman to be totally untraceable. Braxmail, which goes along with it, is an even more impregnable provider than Protonmail or its equivalents. It is an Android phone, and unfortunately where I live it is not compatible with the only reliable provider in my area. So it just wasn't suitable for me. But I loved the Thunderbird program which Braxmail is compatible with. But I can;t get Apple Mail on the Brax phone, and I can't get Braxmail on my iPhone! So I thought if I installed Thunderbird to use with Apple Mail, it would make it easier to transfer the data I have on the Braxmail program (It is supported on my MacBook Pro.). Does any of that help? I even have difficulty explaining all that to myself! Thanks for your response.
creator: pgalewitz

content: Two more things - I want to be able to do without the Brax2 phone, as having two phones is awkward, but I need to be able to access all of my email on my iPhone. Also, I have lots of stuff in the Braxmail program, and I would love to get it all into the Thunderbird supported Apple Mail.
creator: pgalewitz

content: Okay, I have no knowledge of Apple Mail. But, if you are using Thunderbird for Braxmail and want to keep the messages and lose the Brax account, you could (if POP account) - close Thunderbird - in file mode of OS, copy the message folders in the Mail\accountname folder to Local Folders. - then, when restarting Thunderbird, the saved messages would be there and you could remove Braxmail
creator: davidsk

content: I will give this a try, David. Thank you for bearing with me.

content:
If you have feedback to offer, I suggest you use the feedback forum. https://connect.mozilla.org Or there is a link on the Thunderbird help menu.

However. Outgoing servers are a function of an identity in Thunderbird, not an account. As each incoming account can be configured for multiple identities and hence multiple outgoing servers, trying to shoehorn outgoing as part of incoming like is done with say outlook is not really as functional as it is with outlook which only has one identity per account.
creator: MattAuSupport
